title: How to Draw the Koch Snowflake

steps.headline: Draw an equilateral triangle.
steps.description: You can draw it with a compass or protractor, or just eyeball it if you don't want to spend too much time drawing the snowflake. It's best if the length of the sides are divisible by 3, because of the nature of this fractal. This will become clear in the next few steps.

steps.headline: Divide each side in three equal parts.
steps.description: This is why it is handy to have the sides divisible by three.

steps.headline: Draw an equilateral triangle on each middle part.
steps.description: Measure the length of the middle third to know the length of the sides of these new triangles.

steps.headline: Divide each outer side into thirds.
steps.description: You can see the 2 generation of triangles covers a bit of the first. These three line segments shouldn't be parted in three.

steps.headline: Draw an equilateral triangle on each middle part.
steps.description: Note how you draw each next generation of parts that are one 3 of the mast one.

steps.headline: Repeat until you're satisfied with the amount of iterations.
steps.description: It will become harder and harder to accurately draw the new triangles, but with a fine pencil and lots of patience you can reach the 8 iteration. The one shown in the picture is a Koch snowflake of the 4 iteration.

steps.headline: Decorate your snowflake how you like it.
steps.description: You can colour it, cut it out, draw more triangles on the inside, or just leave it the way it is.
